dialogues.speaker: THE SUN" KICKS IN
dialogues.text: The tropical sun pokes its mighty head over the lush gree hills creating a peaceful early morning mist that falls o a beat-up soccer field and the crude dirt track that Surrounds it. A rooster's crowing breaks the eerie silence as a ghost l figure circles the track. This is no weekend jogger. This is: DERICE BANNOCK, Olymp hopeful and one of the island's top sprinters. Derice has face of an African Prince and the long fluid stride of a4 champion. He goes along at an easy pace, then, before you can blink eye, he's sprinting down the straightaway like he was sho out of a cannon. He stretches forward as if he were breaking an imaginary tape. Derice pulls back to a jog and begins his ‘victory waving to the imaginary crowd, one athlete, alone with hi dream, running in the early morning mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We. see TWO POWERFUL FIFTY YEAR-OLD WOMEN carrying big ba of fruit on their heads. They see someone coming their way. It's Derice. He is still jogging, but this is an easier m relaxed pace than before. He breaks into a warm smile as he waves to the women.

dialogues.speaker: DERICE
dialogues.text: (with a casual salute) Morning, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: (teasing) Faster, Bannock, faster!

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Come on, child...You got an Olympics to get te.
Derice gives a small laugh and goes into a higher gear as flies past the two women.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Handsome as a lion that one.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I could watch his bum all day. The two older women giggle like school girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Derice jogs aiong, we see little kids tagging behind h Some drop off as others take their place. From Derice's POV, we see a little snack and soft-drink stand. The sign above it reads ‘UNCLE FERTE'S.' In front the stand, JOSEPH, an old retired fisherman plays dominoe himself on a wobbly card table.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Here he comes! UNCLE FERTE, a seventy year-old man with kind eyes and leathery skin, comes out from behind the stand with a bot of water. Derice grabs the bottle without breaking stride.

dialogues.speaker: FERTE
dialogues.text: (calling after) Go get ‘em, tiger! Ferte comes over to Joseph. They watch Derice run off.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Look at him...He run just like his father.

dialogues.speaker: FERTE
dialogues.text: Wait till the world finds out we got another Bannock. {End credits) EXT. BLUE MOUNTAINS JAMAICA'S PUSHCART DERBY — NOON A nice crowd has shown up for the annual ‘Pushcart Derby’ {The Jamaican version of Soap Box Racing.}

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Derby is 4 big event and has a carnival atmosphere. A live Reggae band turns out the beat as spectators line th mountain road all the way down to the finish line. CLOSE ON: A pushcart. It is painted in the traditional Rastafarian black, green, and red. On the front of the ca printed in bold letters is 'TRENCHTOWN ROCKET! ' Relaxing in the driver's seat, as he looks through a pair binoculars, is SANKA COFFIE, the reigning king of ‘Derby' racing and Derice Bannock‘s best friend. SANKA IS THE ONLY ADULT IN THE RACE. His long ‘Dreadlocks stick out from under his ‘World War I' leather flyer's he and goggles. His outfit is completed with wild tye-dyed flour-sack knickers, red high-tops, and argyle socks. Sanka's POV: A fine EIGHTEEN YEAR-OLD GIRL in a summer dr swayin't in the crowd. As Sanka adjusts the focus on the binoculars, we close in WINSTON, a slight, goofy ten year-old boy. Winston wears beat up American football helmet and is covered in grease grime as he uses all his strength to tighten a loose bolt the cart. Sanka puts the binoculars down and contemplates.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: You know, Winston...As I sit here thinking about all the greatness which is me...I begin to realize what an honor this must be for a boy such as yourself. To ride with the gifted one...The Grand Poobah of the pushcart...Sanka Coffie. We hear a VOICE OFF CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: DERICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: {calls out) Hey, Poobah, when you gonna take on someone your own size?

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Whoever said that better be ready to rumble. Sanka springs to his feet, spins around and sees it's Der

dialogues.text: Where you been, star? I'm about to go for my ail-time record, seventh in a row.

dialogues.speaker: DERICE
dialogues.text: Be easy, ras...You know I ain't gonna forget me best friend on his day of days. Winston jumps up from behind the cart and comes over to Derice.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (interupting him) Hey Derice, my grandpa says you're a cinch to make it to the Olympics. He Says you're gonna be even better than your father.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: And my grandpa says you better get your pee-wee ass back behind that cart...We got a derby to win! Derice can't heip but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OLD RASTA
dialogues.text: On your marks.

dialogues.speaker: JOY

dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.text: Actually, it's 4967 feet...It's a brand new course. No one's ever raced on it...That's why everybody's here early.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Steeper, deeper, and you can keep her. Beat.

dialogues.text: Anybody else cold?

dialogues.text: Cold...Mon? I’m freezin‘ my royal rastafarian nuts off.

dialogues.text: It is a bit chilly.

dialogues.text: Let's bobsled tomorrow.

dialogues.text: Damn, it's a nice day for a sleigh ride. The JAMS put their helmets on. When Sanka puts on his hel his dreads stick out of the bottom, THE WHOLE HILL CRACKS Irv comes up behind the boys.  62.

dialogues.text: Climb in. I don't understand.

dialogues.text: Ain't we gonna push start?

dialogues.text: Hey coach...You gonna tuck them in too?! Irv bristles at the comment. Sanka takes his lucky egg out of his pocket and kisses it

dialogues.speaker: SANKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: @ (turns to Yul) You want to kiss my egg? Yul looks at him like he's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Suit yourself, He carefully puts the egg back inside his sweatshirt. Irv gives his final instructions.

dialogues.text: Everybody, listen up...Don't worry about tryin’ to look good out there...You guys are beginners and that’s nothin' to be embarrassed of. Josef Grool looks on. He whispers something in his buddy' ear and they both crack up.

dialogues.speaker: IRV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Remember, bobsledding ain't like other sports...There's no gettin' your feet wet and seein' if you like it...You gotta dive in and swim for 6 your life...Now, over the next couple of weeks I might do some things that seem a little mean...Believe me, it's all in your best interest. Sanka raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: IRV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What is it, Sanka?

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: I gotta go...(He points to his lap.) You know.

dialogues.speaker: DERICE
dialogues.text: There's no time for that.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Why not? We ain‘t bobsleddin' yet?

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: Oh, yes we are!it Irv kicks the sled with his foot and it starts down the h  64. The sled wobbles off, slowly at first, but then quickly accelerates. The camera follows as the sled starts to fly down the tunnel of ice.

THE ENTIRE SLE FACING BACKWARDS. Junior screams at the top cf his lungs as Sanka prays. Yu grits his teeth. People are forced to jump out of the way, screaming.

dialogues.text: Look at those clowns...Someone's gonna have to stop this.

dialogues.text: Sanka, Yul and Junior are sitting around the room. Junior using a ‘lint roller' on his pants, Yul's playing solitai and Sanka's reading a comic book. A pan of bananas cooks hotplate by Sanka's bed. Yul pulls the reading lamp away from Sanka so it shines o his cards. Sanka pulls it back, but Yul just does it agai

dialogues.text: Shut dat hot plate down, fool...Them bananas stinkin‘ like a dead dog.  65. Sanka ignores Yul, so Yul reaches over Sanka to shut the hotplate off.

dialogues.text: Cut it out, head wax, I'm readin'!

dialogues.text: What you mean readin',..Them things be for little children.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Oh, is that so?

dialogues.speaker: YUL
dialogues.text: Yah, that's so.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Well, if they for little children, that means they too advanced for the likes of you.

dialogues.speaker: YUL
dialogues.text: You sayin' I ain't no smarter than a little child?

dialogues.text: What I'm sayin is, you're the kind of club totin' cave man bastard that counts to ten by stompin' with his foot. Yul goes over to the dresser and starts whippin' through drawers.

dialogues.speaker: YUL
dialogues.text: Go ahead, boy, enjoy yourself. Say whatever you want... We can see Sanka getting nervous. Maybe Yul's looking for gun.

dialogues.speaker: YUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're just like every other fool on the island...Goin' nowhere fast and thrilled to death about it. Yul has found what he was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: YUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you seé, I'm different...I know where I'm goin’...And after I'm famous for winnin’ the Olympics, I'm e@ gonna be livin' right here!
Yul whips around holding a picture postcard of the ‘WHIT e HOUSE.' Sanka sees this and starts to laugh his head of

dialogues.speaker: YUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's so damn funny?

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: (fighting through laughter) That's the White House!

dialogues.speaker: YUL
dialogues.text: I know what color it is...What about it?

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: Nothin' about it...It's just if you plan on livin' there, you gonna have to evict the goddamn president.

dialogues.text: (explaining to Yul) Yul, that's where the president of the United States lives. Yul is so embarrassed he can't speak. He wraps his fist around the postcard and crumples it violently, wishing it @ were Sanka's head, and throws it on the floor.

dialogues.text: Face it, Brenner, you gonna end up in an out-house shanty like every other dockworkin' sucker~Jon.

dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.text: Says me, rich boy. What you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I know my father started off ina one room hut, and now he lives in one of the biggest homes in Kingston.

dialogues.speaker: SANKA
dialogues.text: {re: Yul) Well he ain't your father.  67.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: He doesn't have to be. All he has to do is know what he wants and work hard for it. If he wants it bad enough, he'll get it...Believe me, the more guys like Yul Brenner we got makin' it, the better off this world would be, especially for Jamaicans. Junior goes over and picks up the crumpled postcard. He Straightens it out and hands it back to Yul.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Derice...I know you can do it. All you got to do is stick with it and everything gonna be fine.

dialogues.text: You know...Saporro...Nothin' like a little extra weight in the runners to make your sled go faster?

dialogues.text: (faking) That wasn't no big thing?

dialogues.text: No, just out.

dialogues.text: Signing. Junicr signs. The messenger exits.

dialogues.text: It's a telegram...From my father!

dialogues.text: I know them...Like a letter, only faster. Junior opens the telegram and reads.

dialogues.text: It's over!

dialogues.text: {in shock) He knows. He knows it all...The team, the car, the job, everything. He says either I come home right now or I don't come home at ail.

dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.text: (trance like) In the Omega, this is where I get on, and this is where I get off.

dialogues.text: But you don't understand. He's really mad...When he gets like this it's usually best to just do what he wants.

dialogues.text: (slamming his head and hands on the table)

dialogues.text: Pride.

dialogues.text: Power.
